question: Question_04
statement:
A refining company must produce 70 oz. of gold and 500 oz. of silver
from ore. The ores available for purchase have the following
characteristics.

\begin{longtable}[c]{@{}llll@{}}
Ore type & Cost & Gold yield & Silver yield\\

A & \$300/ton & 1 oz./ton & 20 oz./ton\\
B & \$200/ton & 1 oz./ton & 10 oz./ton\\
C & \$400/ton & 2 oz./ton & 10 oz./ton\\
\end{longtable}

How many tons of each type of ore should be purchased in order to
produce the metals at least cost?
sols:
Let's say we order \emph{a} amount of type \emph{A}, similarly \emph{b}
of type \emph{B} and \emph{c} of type \emph{C}. Thus, the total cost can
be read as

\[\displaystyle 300a + 200b + 400c\]

which is the objective function we must \emph{minimize}.

The variables $a, b, c$ are not arbitrary, but must be chosen so that we
get 70oz of gold and 500oz of silver. A choice of \emph{a,b,c} leads to
two equations relating to the amount of ore purchased:

\textbf{Amount of gold:} $\displaystyle a + b + 2c = 70 \text{oz}$

\textbf{Amount of silver:}
$\displaystyle 20a + 10b + 10c = 500 \text{oz}$

Put this into an extended matrix we get:

$\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 1 & 2 & 70 \\ 
20 & 10 & 10 & 500
\end{array} \right]$

Which we can simplify to the matrix:

$\left[ \begin{array}{ccc|c}
1 & 0 & -1 & -20 \\ 
0 & 1 & 3 & 90
\end{array} \right].$

Thus, we can consider \emph{c} to be a free variable. Solving this
system we get

\begin{align*}
a&=-20+c\\
b&=90-3c\\
\end{align*}

Having written each quantity with respect to \emph{c} we can put it in
the cost equation

\begin{align*}
C=300a + 200b + 400c &= 300(-20 +c) + 200(90 - 3c) + 400c \\
&= -6000 + 300c + 18000 -600c + 400c \\
&= 12000 + 100c
\end{align*}

which we now have to minimize. \emph{C} is an increasing function (it is
linear with positive slope) and so choosing the smallest value of
\emph{c} possible will yield the minimum. It looks like this value may
be \emph{c=0} however looking at the other formulas tells us that if
\emph{c} were zero then \emph{a} would be -20 and \emph{b} would be 90.
We can't order negative quantities of anything so we actually have
hidden constraints, namely that

\[a\geq0,\qquad{}b\geq0,\qquad{}c\geq0.\]

Using our relations for \emph{a} and \emph{b}, this tells us that

\begin{align*}
c&\geq20\\
c&\leq30
\end{align*}

Since we know the cost \emph{C} is an increasing function, we want to
take the smallest \emph{c} allowable which is \textbf{\emph{c = 20}}.
Using the equations above we find that this yields \textbf{\emph{a = 0}}
and \textbf{\emph{b = 30}}.
hints:
Suppose you order \emph{a} amount of type \emph{A}, \emph{b} of type
\emph{B} and \emph{c} of type \emph{C}. What is your objective function
that you want to optimize?

Suppose you order \emph{a} amount of type \emph{A}, \emph{b} of type
\emph{B} and \emph{c} of type \emph{C}. How large is your gold yield?
How large is your silver yield? Can you write this in matrix notation?
Remember that you can not order negative quantities.
